intro: Hieracium psammophilum, commonly known as the sandhill hawkweed, is a flowering plant native to North America, particularly found in sandy or dry habitats. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its yellow flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Hieracium psammophilum is adapted to arid environments, showcasing features that help it conserve water and thrive in nutrient-poor soils.
